list.title: Tepid Peppermint Wonderland: A Retrospective
list.dek: After nearly 15 years, Anton Newcombe and his ever-rotating crew of accomplises in Brian Jonestown Massacre are finally getting the compilation treatment. This two-disc, 33-track collection strips away the feuds, drug use, mental illness, and rock star aura from these subjects of the recent Sundance-winning documentary Dig!, and focuses, for once, on their music.

list.title: Street's Disciple
list.dek: Considering Nas' one-hot-album-every-10-year average, he's due for another great record. The sprawling, two-disc Street's Disciple isn't it, but it's a step in the right direction, as well in a new direction: If the Nas of Illmatic was trying to get out of the ghetto, the Nas of Street's Disciple is trying to get the ghetto out of the ghetto-- and find a decent babysitter.

tout.title: Where Will You Be Christmas Day? cover art

list.title: Where Will You Be Christmas Day?
list.seoTitle: Where Will You Be Christmas Day?
list.socialTitle: Where Will You Be Christmas Day?
list.promoTitle: Where Will You Be Christmas Day?
list.dek: Dust-to-Digital-- the label that last year brought us the magnificent Goodbye, Babylon, a six-disc box set of early gospel music-- spoils us again with...Christmas music? So this holiday season, put down that Burl Ives album and check out this compilation of mostly early 20th century yuletide sounds. Together, these folk, jazz, blues, and calyspo tracks create a quasi-seasonal anthology that you'll still dig out in July, suddenly craving (if not requiring) its quiet, unmatched grace.

list.title: Catch the Breeze
list.dek: This new two-disc compilation neatly cuts through these seminal shoegazers' three-album, multiple-single career, compacting all their best work into one handy, chronologically arranged collection that moves from the lush and delicate to the dark and ominous-- and all while making the case that the band transcended their genre to become both "lost generation" compatriots of post-rock and a massive influence on today's indie-leaning electronic artists.

list.title: The Downward Spiral [Deluxe Edition]
list.dek: Interscope takes further advantage of the holiday shopping blowout with this deluxe edition of yet another 90s alt-rock staple. Here's Trent Reznor's best-known (and most highly regarded) work, The Downward Spiral, bulked up to include Dolby 5.1 surround and SACD mixes, and an entire second disc's worth of B-sides, remixes and rarities.

list.title: The Tigers Have Spoken
list.dek: Neko Case's first live album isn't the usual collection of slightly re-touched studio favorites. In addition to a few requisite live staples, this collection also includes new originals, covers of songs by Loretta Lynn and The Shangri-La's, and a couple of public-domain tracks. Members of The Sadies ably serve as Case's backing band as she moves between vintage torch-and-twang, otherworldly blues, sweet soul music, and plain old rock'n'roll.

list.dek: Matmos audio alchemist Drew Daniel returns with his ambiguously ironic, plunderphonic project, The Soft Pink Truth. His latest excursion seemingly tackles the dancepunk phenomenon with diced-up and often homoerotic disco and microhouse covers of punk classics from the likes of Minor Threat, Crass, Die Kreuzen, The Angry Samoans, Swell Maps, Rudimentary Peni...and Carol Channing.

list.title: DFA Compilation #2
list.dek: DFA Records spoils us with this giant three-disc set celebrating its recent output. The record includes favorites from LCD Soundsystem, The Rapture, Black Dice, and first-time DFA collaborators Liquid Liquid, as well as strong efforts from relative newcomers such as Black Leotard Front, J.O.Y., and Pixeltan. It's a meticulously assembled personal narrative from a label that balances its musical and commercial aspirations with an earthy, no-bullshit disposition and-- let's say it-- the world's best fucking handclaps.

list.socialDescription: DFA Records spoils us with this giant three-disc set celebrating its recent output. The record includes favorites from LCD Soundsystem, The Rapture, Black Dice, and first-time DFA collaborators Liquid Liquid, as well as strong efforts from relative newcomers such as Black Leotard Front, J.O.Y., and Pixeltan. It's a meticulously assembled personal narrative from a label that balances its musical and commercial aspirations with an earthy, no-bullshit disposition and-- let's say it-- the world's best fucking handclaps.

list.title: Matador at Fifteen
list.dek: A half-decade on from Matador's 10th-anniversary compilation, Everything Is Nice*, the venerable indie label celebrates another landmark. Matador at 15 is two CDs (one a "best of" collection and the other a rarities set) and one DVD encompassing the label's work between 2000-04, and features Interpol, Stephen Malkmus, Belle & Sebastian, Cat Power, Yo La Tengo, Cornelius, and Pretty Girls Make Graves, and others.

list.dek: After a handful of singles, a trio of stellar mixes, and an impressive body of work as Nettle, Jace Clayton finally drops his first dj/Rupture album. Clayton translates his multicultural, multinational mix approach to the LP, which features Western and Arabic musicians, tracks sung in English, French, and Spanish, and guest spots from dancehall MCs Sister Nancy and Junior Cat.

list.title: Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain: LA's Desert Origins

list.socialTitle: Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain: LA's Desert Origins
list.promoTitle: Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain: LA's Desert Origins
list.dek: Pavement's Slanted & Enchanted: Luxe & Reduxe-- packed with top-quality extras at a low price-- was a near-perfect example of how to reissue an already beloved record. Matador now gives the same treatment to that album's equally classic 1994 follow-up. The result, Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain: LA's Desert Origins, is a two-disc remastered reissue, featuring 49 total tracks collecting B-sides, comp tracks and outtakes, including 25 unreleased recordings and 11 unheard tracks.

list.title: Has Been
list.dek: Self-deprecating pop culture icon's first full-length since 1968's legendarily silly The Transformed Man features collaborations with Henry Rollins, Ben Folds, Joe Jackson, and King Crimson's Adrian Belew, as well as a notorious cover of Pulp's "Common People" and a song written by High Fidelity author and pop music critic Nick Hornby.
